text: Alteration of a single serine in the basic domain of the Epstein-Barr virus <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein separates its functions of transcriptional activation and disruption of latency .
The <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein from Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) activates a switch from the latent to the lytic expression program of the virus .

<extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a member of the bZIP family of DNA - binding proteins , is a transcriptional activator capable of inducing expression from viral lytic cycle promoters .

It had previously been thought that <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> 's capacity to disrupt EBV latency resided primarily in its ability to activate transcription of genes that encode products required for lytic replication .

We generated a point mutant of <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , Z ( S186A ) , that was not impaired in its ability to activate transcription ; however , this mutation abolished its ability to initiate the viral lytic cascade .

The mutant , containing a serine - to-alanine substitution in the DNA - binding domain of the protein , bound to several known <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding sites and activated transcription from reporters bearing known <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - responsive promoters but did not disrupt latency in EBV-infected cell lines .

Therefore , initiation of the EBV lytic cycle by the <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein requires a function in addition to transcriptional activation ; a change of serine 186 to alanine in the DNA - binding domain of <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> abolished this additional function and uncovered a new role for the <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein in disruption of EBV latency .

The additional function that is required for initiation of the lytic viral life cycle is likely to require phosphorylation of serine 186 of the <extra_id_0> ZEBRA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein , which may influence either DNA recognition or transcriptional activation of lytic viral promoters in a chromatinized viral episome .
